statements: SELECT * FROM hr_employees;
SELECT employee_id, first_name, last_name FROM hr_employees;
SELECT employee_id, first_name, last_name, department FROM hr_employees;
SELECT * FROM hr_employees WHERE department = 'IT';
SELECT * FROM hr_employees WHERE hire_date > '2021-01-01';
SELECT * FROM hr_employees WHERE department = 'HR' AND hire_date > '2020-01-01';
SELECT first_name, last_name FROM hr_employees WHERE department = 'Marketing';
SELECT * FROM hr_employees WHERE first_name LIKE 'J%';
SELECT * FROM hr_employees WHERE last_name = 'Doe';
SELECT * FROM hr_employees WHERE department IS NULL;
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM hr_employees;
SELECT MAX(hire_date) FROM hr_employees;
SELECT MIN(hire_date) FROM hr_employees;
SELECT AVG(employee_id) FROM hr_employees;
SELECT COUNT(*) AS total_employees FROM hr_employees;
SELECT first_name, last_name, hire_date FROM hr_employees ORDER BY hire_date DESC;
SELECT department, COUNT(*) AS total_employees FROM hr_employees GROUP BY department;
SELECT department, AVG(employee_id) AS avg_employee_id FROM hr_employees GROUP BY department;
SELECT department, hire_date, COUNT(*) AS num_employees FROM hr_employees GROUP BY department, hire_date;
SELECT department, hire_date, COUNT(*) AS num_employees FROM hr_employees GROUP BY department, hire_date HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;
SELECT * FROM employees;
SELECT name, age, position FROM employees;
SELECT * FROM employees WHERE age > 30;
SELECT name, salary FROM employees WHERE position = 'Manager';
SELECT * FROM departments;
SELECT name, location FROM departments;
SELECT * FROM departments WHERE location = 'New York';
SELECT e.name, d.name FROM employees e INNER JOIN departments d ON e.id = d.id;
SELECT e.name, e.position, d.location FROM employees e INNER JOIN departments d ON e.id = d.id;
SELECT e.name AS employee_name, d.name AS department_name FROM employees e INNER JOIN departments d ON e.id = d.id;
SELECT e.name, SUM(e.salary) AS total_salary FROM employees e GROUP BY e.name;
SELECT d.name, COUNT(e.id) AS num_employees FROM departments d LEFT JOIN employees e ON d.id = e.id GROUP BY d.name;
SELECT d.name, MAX(e.salary) AS highest_salary FROM departments d LEFT JOIN employees e ON d.id = e.id GROUP BY d.name;
SELECT e.name, AVG(e.salary) AS avg_salary FROM employees e GROUP BY e.name HAVING AVG(e.salary) > 50000;
SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY age DESC;
SELECT * FROM employees ORDER BY salary ASC;
SELECT * FROM employees LIMIT 10;
SELECT * FROM employees OFFSET 5;
SELECT DISTINCT position FROM employees;
SELECT MAX(age) AS max_age, MIN(age) AS min_age FROM employees;
SELECT * FROM employee WHERE id = 1
SELECT id, name FROM employee WHERE department = 'HR'
SELECT name, department FROM employee ORDER BY name ASC
SELECT * FROM department WHERE location = 'New York'
SELECT id, name FROM department WHERE name LIKE '%Eng%'
SELECT employee.id, employee.name, salary.amount FROM employee JOIN salary ON employee.id = salary.employee_id
SELECT employee.name, salary.amount FROM employee JOIN salary ON employee.id = salary.employee_id WHERE salary.amount > 50000
SELECT department.name, AVG(salary.amount) FROM department JOIN employee ON department.id = employee.id JOIN salary ON employee.id = salary.employee_id GROUP BY department.name
SELECT DISTINCT department.name FROM department JOIN employee ON department.id = employee.id JOIN salary ON employee.id = salary.employee_id WHERE salary.amount > 60000
SELECT employee.name, SUM(salary.amount) FROM employee JOIN salary ON employee.id = salary.employee_id GROUP BY employee.name HAVING SUM(salary.amount) > 100000
SELECT * FROM employees;
SELECT id, first_name, last_name, department FROM employees;
SELECT first_name, last_name, salary FROM employees;
SELECT * FROM departments;
SELECT id, name, location FROM departments;
SELECT * FROM positions;
SELECT title, description FROM positions;
SELECT * FROM benefits;
SELECT type, description FROM benefits;
SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, departments.name FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department = departments.id;
SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, positions.title FROM employees JOIN positions ON employees.department = positions.department_id;
SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, benefits.type FROM employees JOIN benefits ON employees.id = benefits.employee_id;

SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, positions.title, benefits.type FROM employees JOIN positions ON employees.department = positions.department_id JOIN benefits ON employees.id = benefits.employee_id;

SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, departments.name, positions.title, benefits.type FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department = departments.id JOIN positions ON employees.department = positions.department_id JOIN benefits ON employees.id = benefits.employee_id;

SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, departments.name, benefits.type FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department = departments.id JOIN benefits ON employees.id = benefits.employee_id;

SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, departments.name, positions.title FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department = departments.id JOIN positions ON employees.department = positions.department_id;
SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, departments.location FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department = departments.id;
SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, positions.description FROM employees JOIN positions ON employees.department = positions.department_id;
SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, benefits.description FROM employees JOIN benefits ON employees.id = benefits.employee_id;

SELECT employees.first_name, employees.last_name, departments.name, positions.description, benefits.type FROM employees JOIN departments ON employees.department = departments.id JOIN positions ON employees.department = positions.department_id JOIN benefits ON employees.id = benefits.employee_id;
